verses.text: After twenty years, during which Solomon had built the house of the LORD and his own royal palace,
verses.comment: Solomon’s dedication to building the temple and his palace demonstrates the importance of both divine worship and ordered kingship (see 1 Kings 9:10). These are foundational to God's plan for Israel.

verses.text: Solomon rebuilt the cities that Huram had given him, and settled Israelites there.
verses.comment: The mutual exchange of cities with King Huram (Hiram) of Tyre highlights international cooperation and the expansion of Israel’s territory. Huram aiding Solomon also points to Gentiles participating in God's work (compare with Luke 7:2-10).

verses.text: Then Solomon went to Hamath-zobah and took it.
verses.comment: Hamath-zobah’s capture extends the dominion of Israel, echoing the continued fulfillment of God’s promise to Abraham regarding the land (Gen. 15:18).

verses.text: He built Tadmor in the wilderness, as well as all the storage cities that he built in Hamath.
verses.comment: Tadmor (Palmyra) and the storage cities reflect Solomon’s wisdom in administration and preparation – a pattern of stewardship found in the faith (see Luke 19:13).

verses.text: He also built Upper Beth-horon and Lower Beth-horon, fortified cities with walls, gates, and bars,
verses.comment: The construction and fortification of these cities show the importance of ordered defense and strategic planning for God’s people.

verses.text: and Baalath, and all the storage cities that belonged to Solomon, and all the cities for his chariots and horses, and whatever Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, Lebanon, and throughout all the land of his dominion.
verses.comment: The vast scope of Solomon’s projects highlights his prosperity and the peace during his reign. The detail in naming chariot cities shows a kingdom richly organized and ordered – a type pointing forward to Christ the King and the order of His kingdom.

verses.text: All the people who were left of the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, who were not of Israel,
verses.comment: This verse recalls Israel’s history of conquest and the survival of some non-Israelite peoples among them. This sets up the structure for service and labor in the kingdom.

verses.text: their descendants who had been left in the land, whom the people of Israel had not destroyed—Solomon made them do forced labor to this day.
verses.comment: The use of non-Israelite forced labor is a historical reality but is not depicted as an ideal in later revelation (see Eph. 6:9). Still, Solomon’s rule prefigures the coming of a greater King, in whom all nations find unity.

verses.text: But of the Israelites Solomon did not make slaves for his work; they were soldiers, commanders, officers, and captains of his chariots and horsemen.
verses.comment: Israelites served as leaders and military men, not as slaves. This distinction foreshadows the restored dignity and royal priesthood that God intends for His people (1 Pet. 2:9).

verses.text: These were the chief officers of King Solomon, two hundred and fifty, who ruled over the people.
verses.comment: The order and hierarchy established by Solomon reflect wise governance. Ordered leadership is a pattern continued into the New Testament Church (Acts 6:3).

verses.text: Solomon brought Pharaoh’s daughter up from the city of David to the house he had built for her, for he said, 'My wife shall not live in the house of David king of Israel, because the places have become holy, where the ark of the LORD has entered.'
verses.comment: Solomon’s care for holiness shows respect for sacred space. Separation between common and holy things is a key biblical theme, later fulfilled through Christ’s sanctification of His people (Heb. 2:11).

verses.text: Then Solomon offered burnt offerings to the LORD on the altar of the LORD which he had built before the porch,
verses.comment: Faithful and continual sacrifice marks Solomon’s worship. These sacrifices point ahead to the once-for-all sacrifice of Christ (Heb. 10:10-14).

verses.text: according to the daily requirement of each day, offering according to the commandment of Moses, for the Sabbaths, the New Moons, and the fixed feasts, three times a year: the Feast of Unleavened Bread, the Feast of Weeks, and the Feast of Booths.
verses.comment: Solomon’s adherence to Moses’ law in offering at appointed seasons connects the king with priestly duties. These biblical feasts prefigure Christian celebrations, fulfilled in the life and ministry of Christ.

verses.text: According to the order of his father David, he appointed the divisions of the priests for their service, and the Levites for their offices of praise and ministry beside the priests, as the daily duty required. And the gatekeepers by their divisions at each gate, for so David the man of God had commanded.
verses.comment: The careful arrangement of priests, Levites, and gatekeepers stems from David’s commands, showing the continuity and tradition ordered by God’s chosen leaders. This prefigures the structured liturgy and music in Christian worship.

verses.text: They did not turn aside from what the king commanded to the priests and Levites, in any matter concerning the treasuries.
verses.comment: Obedience to the king’s command aligns with God’s original instructions. The focus on faithfulness in service and stewardship points to the importance of order and obedience in the household of faith.

verses.text: Now all the work of Solomon was accomplished from the day the foundation of the house of the LORD was laid until it was finished. So the house of the LORD was completed.
verses.comment: The completion of the temple fulfills David’s preparation and Solomon’s obedience. The finished temple points towards the greater temple, Christ Himself, and the building up of His people as a holy temple (Eph. 2:21-22).

verses.text: Then Solomon went to Ezion-geber and Eloth on the shore of the sea, in the land of Edom.
verses.comment: Solomon’s ventures to Ezion-geber and Eloth reflect interests in trade and international reach. This foreshadows the gospel reaching Gentile nations from Israel’s shores.

verses.text: And Huram sent to him by his servants ships and servants who understood the sea. They went to Ophir along with Solomon’s servants, and brought from there 450 talents of gold, and brought it to King Solomon.
verses.comment: The procurement of gold from Ophir shows the prosperity that flowed to Israel under Solomon, attracting Gentile collaboration. Israel’s blessing foreshadows the gathering of all nations into the worship of the one true God.
